page.title: 03The North Light.
page.content: The North Light is now unmanned and since 1978 has been controlled automatically from the South Light. An armoured cable connects the two and the resistance is checked frequently. The light stands 165 feet above sea level.It gives two white flashes every twenty seconds.A radio beacon transmits a call sign every five minutes.In conjunction with call signs from the South Light this enables ships to take cross bearings. Supplies used to reach the lighthouse by winch and tramway.A steep flight of steps descends past Kittiwake Gully to a landing place below.This is a good place to see seals-as is all the coast between N.W.Point and N.E.Point.Seals can often be seen basking on Seal's Rock and other rocks nearby.
